poem:
Title: In Memory of a Great Tit

Life and death converse in soft garden whispers,
A child's hands, cradling a still, feathered form.
"Sleeping bird," he declares, 
Innocent testament of transience.
"We lay thee down," a mother's sombre litany,
Shovelling earth over the promise of flight.
No more bird, but a lesson in loss,
Etched upon the flesh of a maturing heart.
